results.title: Project out of school: planning a quality service
results.creator_credit: Alex Jaye, Maryla Juchnowski, Suzanne Cecil-Fizdale and Video Media Production
results.brief_description: Provides the considerations for planning quality out of school programs both before and after school. Shows a number of active programs, emphasises the advantages of holding such programs, and illustrates ways of involving parents, children and staff. Appropriate for Professional Development and Personal Development (Home Economics) at VCE level

results.title: Precision
results.creator_credit: Georges Dufaux, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Here is the famed Royal Canadian Mounted Police Musical Ride, filmed in a way that gives it all the unison of a chorus line. An extremely sophisticated exercise in patterned movement of horses and riders, the Musical Ride entails pinpoint precision. In this film the camera challenges this virtuosity from every angle, including a position directly above the platoon. The resulting blend of music, color, movement and, of course, fine horsemanship, is exciting to see. (Awards: Locarno)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Georges Dufaux, Jacques Bobet and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Project grizzly
results.creator_credit: Peter Lynch, Michael Allder and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Troy Hurtubise on 18th May 2002, once again made the news with a demonstration of his latest grizzly bear suit ‘Ursus Mark VII’. ‘Project grizzly’ documents his story. Troy Hurtubise’s obsession was given birth to over 10 years ago when he was confronted by a grizzly bear whilst trekking alone in the Canadian wilderness. Under an extraordinary set of circumstances the grizzly spares Troy’s life and so an obsession is born. The task Troy set himself is to build a suit that will withstand an attack from a grizzly bear. The mission is to again confront ‘Old Man’ (Troy’s name for the grizzly) whilst wearing the suit to continue his “close quarter bear research”. After $150,000 has been spent and 6 proto-types later Troy takes us through the joys and tribulations of his experimentation whilst admitting that he suffers from claustrophobia. By the end of the documentary we see Troy in suit being bashed with base-ball bats, lead balls and hit by a 3-tonne truck travelling at 50km/h - 18 times! So will Troy get his sniff of ‘Old Man’ or will the transport of the suit impede the project? Also shown is a reconstructed Ska-Nah-Doht, a traditional Iroquoian village.

results.title: Project expansion
results.creator_credit: Robert Walker, Ross Wood and Ross Wood Productions
results.brief_description: A major expansion program, begun by New Broken Hill Consolidated Ltd, in 1968, was completed in 1971. The film describes the expansion activities, which included the sinking of a three-thousand foot air shaft and major extensions to the underground workings. Many views of modern mining methods are provided. Could be used for geography, secondary social studies, and for general interest.

results.title: Goodbye war
results.creator_credit: Donna Dudinsky, Barbara Sears, Judith Merritt and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “War”.
For centuries the international system of states has settled questions of power, territory, national pride and sovereignty with military force. At any given time there are about twenty wars being waged in the international neighbourhood, and in all of them, the people have a particular goal they want to achieve, a goal which they believe outweighs the cost of war. Dyer looks at a number of recent examples. He also examines the efforts of citizens’ peace movements in Europe, in the USA and in the Soviet Union. He suggests that we must find an alternative to war if the planet is to survive.

results.title: Keeping the old game alive
results.creator_credit: Douglas Kiefer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “War”.
Every autumn in central Europe, the combined forces of fifteen member countries of NATO meet to conduct their war games - the most elaborate dress rehersal for World War III. Dyer examines some of the technically sophisticated conventional weaponry used by modern armies and outlines the nightmarish effects of chemical weapons on unprotected civilians.

results.title: Deadly game of nations
results.creator_credit: Paul Cowan, Bill Brind, John Kramer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “War”.
All through history, wars have been linked to feelings of nationalism. There is hardly any country in the world that did not establish iself by means of wars. In this film Gwynne Dyer explors some of the reasons why pople, and governments acting on their behalf, feel the need to keep armies and fight wars. It focuses on Israel’s struggle for a secure place amongst the Arab nations of the Middle East, and on the so far unsuccessful attempts of the Palestinians to create a nation of their own.

results.title: Profession of arms
results.creator_credit: Michael Bryans, Tina Viljoen and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “War”.
(War series 3) This video is about professional soldiers - the career officers in every country who devote their lives to maintaining military organizations and nurturing the attitides that go with them.
